post_info.post_title: Isn't "Adam and Eve" just a way of saying man is flawed?

I will admit my ignorance. 
 I thought that the only intereptation of the Adam and Eve Story was just a long winded way of saying man is flawed. What else is there?

 
 I guess you are not understanding the Hebrew involved. There are plenty of puns, a lot of political references, and bunch of 'just so' stories in there.
 
 For example, ADAM means mankind, and is related to the term 'dirt' Adamah, also known as 'red clay'. Adamah is also related to the term 'edom' which means blood. 
 
 The term 'created' is the term that potter would used for forming pots. So, if you look at the sentace 'God created man out of dirt', you could see the subtles such as 'God formed mankind out of flesh and blood' similar to the way a potter forms pots out clay'. 
 
 the Hebrew for Eve is related to two word, LOVE and LIFE. 
 
 So, God gave mankind love and life for companionship. 
 
 The concept of man being 'flaws' because of adam and eve is something that was added by Paul, and expanded up on by Saint Augustus. It is not inherent in the text of Genesis if you are educated with some of the deeper, allegoricial meanings of Adam and EVe.

So, God gave mankind love and life for companionship. 
 
 

 
 It's also helpful to understand the word mankind is composed of two separate words. MANK and IND. 
 
 I just don't make any sense of it.

It's also helpful to understand the word mankind is composed of two separate words. MANK and IND.

in taking genesis literally, you accept that God is all-powerful, and that man has sinned and is need of redemption. if the events in genesis did not occur in reality, then there is no reason to believe that God is all-powerful in reality, nor that man is sinful and in need of redemption in reality. therefore there is no reason to believe that christianity (based on the premises i described above) is a valid religion if genesis is not taken literally
 
 anything is possible in fiction (including making 5-sided round squares, eating burritos too hot to eat, and creating people from dirt)

I'm hesitant to attach human frailties to God. If we agree that God is omnipotent, it is foolish to limit his powers to those we understand or can accept as physical possibilities. It is unimaginable that any human could do that, therefore hard to imagine God doing it. This is likely why I believe the 6-day creation is an allegory. I don't believe earth came before the sun. I don't believe God spoke the sun into existence. I believe He set the whole thing in motion and things happened from there, taking millions of years to develop into stars, planets, etc. There are star nurseries spitting out baby stars as we speak. Our sun was just one of them. Perhaps another habitable planet will develop and life will be introduced to it and evolve into many species ruled by intelligent beings, just as it did here. Perhaps this has already happened in a number of places.
 
 It is extremely difficult to believe that our little earth is the only place in the universe where lifeforms came to be.
 
 I believe it is reasonable to assume that God is capable of doing those things, but those are not necessarily the ways He made them.

Not entirely. The fact that we have never seen them flying at that altitude as little to do with lack of belief that they could. So the sentence, "never having seen fish flying at that altitude, we have NO REASON to believe it is possible" puts undue value on the fact that we have not seen them do it. My hesitancy in believing they can fly at all is based on their structure and physical restraints rather than the fact that I have not seen it happen. This is much the same as in my never having seen an alien spacecraft should not imply that they do not exist. Not having experienced (seen) something is no reason to believe it doesn't exist.

 i'd say that faith and reason are mutually exclusive, in that faith can only exist in the absence of reason. a combination of faith and reason can bring us to a belief, but as reason (evidence) increases, faith necessarily decreases. for example, the first time on a high-speed roller coaster, your belief in the reliability of the roller coaster may be mainly faith based (80% faith, 20% reason). then as you get more familiar from repeatedly riding the coaster and returning safely consistently, your belief may become 2% faith, 98% reason. of course, in your mind the possibility is that something unpredictible might happen still exists
 
 faith is the opposite of reason

 ron, without a doubt, the more one learns about reality, the more they lose their "childlike purity". its just a fact. maturity is the absence of childishness. it doesnt come with age, but with knowledge and experience. yes there are mature christians, but the more mature they become, the more they filter out parts of the bible that dont make sense to them. it is simply impossible to have knowledge of reality and still accept the bible as true. the person will have to suppress one or they other, because they both contradict.
 
 jesus admonishes his disciples to be like children because children are innocent and trusting. children are full of hope and admire their elders (well, back in those days lol). however, as one matures and gains knowledge, these qualities are replaced with caution, wisdom, skepticism and level-headedness. they are not spurred on by an idealistic utopia, but are sucked into the droning routine of day-to-day reality. of course the child-like qualities make for a more blissful existence, but its bliss at the cost of being oblivious to reality

A state of mind that is a guarantee of absolutely noting to absolutely no one.
 
 (Science and progress.)
 
 hit them over the head with the darkness of the bible and religian.
 
 Now that science has come to understand and treat the consepts of bipolar and mental depression are the christian communities ready to step forward and stop blaming God and demons for everything that thay do not understand???

 that will never happen. the more ignorance and unanswered questions exist, the more gaps for god to fill in. ANYTHING unexpected or unexplained is the work of god in the theist view

ron, without a doubt, the more one learns about reality, the more they lose their "childlike purity". its just a fact. maturity is the absence of childishness. it doesnt come with age, but with knowledge and experience. yes there are mature christians, but the more mature they become, the more they filter out parts of the bible that dont make sense to them. it is simply impossible to have knowledge of reality and still accept the bible as true. the person will have to suppress one or they other, because they both contradict.
 
 jesus admonishes his disciples to be like children because children are innocent and trusting. children are full of hope and admire their elders (well, back in those days lol). however, as one matures and gains knowledge, these qualities are replaced with caution, wisdom, skepticism and level-headedness. they are not spurred on by an idealistic utopia, but are sucked into the droning routine of day-to-day reality. of course the child-like qualities make for a more blissful existence, but its bliss at the cost of being oblivious to reality

 I can't say how you are, unkerpaulie, (nor anyone else here) in real life, or how you carry yourself in the face of adversity, but don't you agree that most "learned" people apply their own "logic" to the humdrum, droning of everyday life? It's human nature to feel burdened with problems that can't be worked out or with troubles that seem routine. Daily stress and pressures of the "fast lane" take even the most dedicated religious leaders aback. I consider knowledge power, just as you do, or anyone else for that matter, but I've come to the conclusion that the Lord has given us a way out - not shunning responsibility - but being able to cope with it according to the Gospel. The Gospel, btw, is not just a copious supply of spiritual edicts, but a way of life. I realize that Christianity has been donned with the wrong kind of armor due to its "label" from the Crusades and Inquisitions, but knowledge has been filtering out that mindset slowly, but surely, even though there are still those that hold to its sinful doctrine.
 Child-like faith comes with the acceptance that someone in authority is in control and that your problems are merely avenues of discovery - knowledge, if you will. The more of that sort of knowledge that a person acquires, the more they are able to solidify their faith and the more trust they have in God. That's my point. There's nothing wrong with remaining pure and innocent - and having the lap of a Father in which to sit when things go wrong. The Bible, as a whole, is telling us just that - and along came Christ to prove it - especially this part:
 
 jesus admonishes his disciples to be like children because children are innocent and trusting.

 What is so wrong with it?

 Child-like faith comes with the acceptance that someone in authority is in control and that your problems are merely avenues of discovery - knowledge, if you will. The more of that sort of knowledge that a person acquires, the more they are able to solidify their faith and the more trust they have in God. That's my point. There's nothing wrong with remaining pure and innocent - and having the lap of a Father in which to sit when things go wrong. The Bible, as a whole, is telling us just that - and along came Christ to prove it - especially this part:
 
 What is so wrong with it?

 we are saying the same thing from different angles. the mental pacifier that god will take care of you does relieve stress for the person that feels the situation they are in is overwhelming them. however, like any other mind altering substance, the problem itself doesnt go away just because you've willed yourself into believing it has. on the positive side, the mental state of telling yourself "god is with me, therefore i can defeat this" is a fantastic affirmation, and guess what, the individual overcomes the problem. in this light there really is nothing wrong with seeing oneself as subjected to god
 
 however, realistically, it goes to show that, like in every situation that one can come across, how overwhelming it gets is nothing more than what the mind believes. if the mind believes that the condition is futile, then it becomes truth and the situation defeats you. however, once the mind says it is capable of handing and mastering the situation, the same becomes truth and the situation becomes and accomplished task. this holds whether you believe in god or not.
 
 the main difference is that the believer believes he could only overcome the siyuation with the help of god, while the non-believer believes that his own internal resolve is what causes him to overcome the situation. the results of both cases are the same, and really neither is "wrong". its more or less a matter of preference
